### III.3 Interpretation  

Table 3 establishes a robust relation between IO and efficiency, but the evidence is insufficient to infer that institutions cause prices to be more efficient. Institutions could prefer to hold stocks that are more efficient. Alternatively, they may select stocks based on a characteristic that is correlated with future efficiency. Both of these scenarios would result in a positive relationship between efficiency and institutional holdings, but institutional holdings would not cause greater efficiency. In this section, we consider these possibilities and provide evidence that causality does in fact run from $I O$ to efficiency.  

#### II1.3.1 Liquidity effects vs. institutional holding effects  

The ability of arbitrageurs to reduce mispricing depends crucially on a stock's liquidity: the less liquid a stock is, the lower are the rewards to eliminating mispricing. Therefore, more liquid stocks should be more efficiently priced. This has implications for the relation between holdings and efficiency. If  

institutions are attracted to more liquid stocks (see Table 2) and liquidity is relatively persistent, the results in Table 3 could be driven by a form of reverse causality. That is, institutions may hold stocks with relatively efficient prices simply because such stocks are more liquid. This possibility warrants careful controls for the relationship between liquidity and efficiency. Since our tests in Table 3 consider only a single proxy for liquidity, RES, and only a linear functional form, additional analyses are needed to address these concerns.  

We first investigate whether the result in Table 3 is specific to RES as a proxy for liquidity. We estimate regressions that are identical except for the liquidity proxy. Specifically, we replace RES with one of the following four measures: effective spreads measured in dollars $(E S)$ , quoted spreads measured in dollars $(Q S)$ , relative quoted spreads $(R Q S)$ , and $\mathcal{Q}S$ divided by the quoted depth (quoted spreads and depths are time weighted). Panel A in Table 4 reports the average coefficients on $I O$ and the liquidity measures (the regressions include the same controls as those in Table 3 but we do not tabulate their coefficients). Similar to Table 3, greater $I O$ is always associated with significantly greater efficiency - the way in which we measure liquidity has no effect on our main result.  

Next, we use a double sort on liquidity and $I O$ to ascertain that variation in $I O$ affects efficiency beyond the direct effect that liquidity has on efficiency. In contrast to the regressions in Table 3, this approach allows for a non-linear relationship between efficiency and both liquidity and $I O$ . We divide the sample into quintiles based on RES that are further divided into three groups based on the $30^{\mathrm{th}}$ and $70^{\mathrm{th}}$ percentile of $I O$ . Panel B in Table 4 reports the relative pricing errors for this double sort. As expected, efficiency increases monotonically with liquidity. But more importantly, efficiency also increases monotonically with $I O$ within each liquidity quintile. This result is not specific to RES as a liquidity measure - we obtain similar results using the other measures from Panel A (not reported). This suggests that institutional holdings have an effect on efficiency that is orthogonal to the liquidity effect.  

Our analysis so far is in terms of levels; if both efficiency and $I O$ were subject to trends, spurious relationships could arise. To address this concern, we relate changes in liquidity and $I O$ to changes in efficiency. More precisely, we first sort the sample stocks into those that experience liquidity increases and those experiencing liquidity decreases between quarters $t{-}1$ and $t$ . Then we split each group into small and large changes at their respective medians. Second, we sort each of the four groups into increases and decreases in $I O$ during quarter $t$ Again, we divide both into large and small changes. Finally, we compute the efficiency change between quarter $t{-}1$ and $_{t+1}$ for each of these groups. We repeat this exercise for four different liquidity measures. When liquidity is measured with RES and RQS, we use $V(s)/V(p)$ to measure efficiency; when liquidity is measured in dollars (ES and $Q S$ ), we use In(s) as the efficiency variable.  

Panel C of Table 4 reports the results for large (above group median) changes in liquidity and $I O$ For changes in relative spread measures, we document strong liquidity effects - increases in relative spreads reduce efficiency and decreases improve efficiency. This effect is absent for the dollar spread measures, probably because the test does not control for the price level. But the more noteworthy result is that increases in $I O$ lead to significantly greater efficiency improvements than decreases in $I O$ , holding constant the change in liquidity. This result is consistent across liquidity measures. Moreover, an increase in institutional holdings improves efficiency even when liquidity worsens. This again suggests that the $I O$ effect is distinct from the liquidity effect and that our results are not sensitive to the way in which we control for variation in liquidity.17  

#### II1.3.2 Reverse causality  

To empirically address the direction of causality, we exploit the time-series dimension of our sample and use a Granger causality test. Specifically, we run time series regressions for each firm having at least 40 quarterly observations and report mean coefficients. Corresponding to the cross-sectional analysis, we first model the change in efficiency as a linear function of lagged changes in $I O$ efficiency, RES, and market value. Panel A of Table 5 presents regression estimates for the four efficiency measures used previously. Increases in $I O$ are always associated with next-quarter increases in efficiency and are statistically significant when we use pricing errors or short-run autocorrelations to measure efficiency.  

Next, we regress changes in $I O$ on lagged changes in $I O$ efficiency, RES, and market value to model reverse causality. Panel B shows that changes in $I O$ are not related to past changes in efficiency. In fact, the (in) efficiency coefficients are all positive, which is the opposite of what would expect if institutions increase holdings when efficiency improves. We repeat the experiments from Table 5 with our other four liquidity measures and find qualitatively similar results (not reported). These results suggest that $I O$ causes efficiency and not vice versa.  

## IV. How do institutions improve efficiency?  

Our analysis shows that the relative efficiency of prices increases with institutional share holdings. To understand the economic mechanisms that drive this result, we explore potential avenues through which institutions could influence this key dimension of market quality. We begin our analysis with the most plausible candidate, institutional trading activity, and establish that it is one channel through which institutions improve efficiency. Then we take a closer look and assess the importance of active and passive trading. We investigate whether the efficiency-enhancing effect is limited to aggressive strategies and shed some light on the role of private information in this respect. We also provide some evidence on how the effect of trading differs across stocks. Finally, we consider three channels that can link institutional holdings per se to efficiency: increased information production through greater ownership concentration, better analyst coverage, and more short selling through a greater supply of lendable shares.  

### IV.1 The role of institutional trading activity  

We begin by looking at the quantity traded by institutions, which we can directly observe in the daily sample. We estimate efficiency on a daily basis and use daily cross-sectional regressions of lnV(s) on lagged institutional trading, lagged daily controls for price volatility, relative effective spreads, volume-weighted average price, and prior-quarter controls for market value and institutional holdings. We use two different measures of institutional trading activity, one standardized by shares outstanding and another standardized by total volume. Panel A of Table 6 shows average daily regression coefficients and significance levels based on Newey- West standard errors. As in Table 3, lower execution costs, higher share price, larger market capitalization, and less price volatility are associated with smaller pricing errors. The coefficient on institutional trading is significantly negative in both models, suggesting that trading is one mechanism by which institutions affect the quality of prices. Even at the daily frequency, however, trading does not drive out the effect of institutional holdings ${}-I O$ coefficients remain significant. This is a somewhat surprising result, because it implies that holdings have an effect on efficiency that goes beyond the effect of trading activity. We will return to this finding in Section IV.4.18  

The daily sample covers only a little more than four years and we would like to corroborate our estimates using the longer, quarterly sample. Because we cannot directly measure institutional trading for the quarterly sample, we use the daily sample to identify publicly observable proxies for institutional trading. Based on the CAUD data, we create three quarterly measures of actual institutional trading in each stock: lnlvol, the (log) level of institutional volume; Ivol/Shrout, the level standardized by shares outstanding; and Ivol/Totvol, the level as a fraction of total volume (results are qualitatively identical for dollar-based volume measures). Then we use these variables to validate quarterly proxies for institutional activity that can be computed from 13-f or CRSP data. From CRSP, we consider the (log) level of trading volume and turnover (share volume scaled by shares outstanding). From the 13-f data, we sum absolute changes in holdings across all institutions to obtain a lower bound of shares traded by institutions. For this variable, we consider the level, the level scaled by shares outstanding, and the level scaled by share Volume.19  

Panel B of Table 6 shows average quarterly cross-sectional correlations over the 2000-2004 time period between the three CAUD-based trading measures (rows) and the potential quarterly proxies (first five columns) along with $I O$ . In terms of levels, institutional volume is highly correlated with the 13-f based measure ( $\scriptstyle(\mathrm{p}{=}0.92)$ o, but it is even more correlated with total trading volume $\left(\mathrm{\uprho{=}0.97}\right.\mathrm{.}$ 0.When standardized by shares outstanding, the correlations are 0.44 (13-f) and 0.63 (CRSP). Therefore, measures based on changes in 13-f holdings and total volume do well as institutional trading proxies when expressed either as levels or as turnover. In contrast, changes in institutional holdings standardized by total volume are completely unrelated to actual institutional trading. A potential reason is that this variable is constructed as the ratio of two variables that by themselves are excellent proxies for institutional trading, so that the resulting ratio is invariant to changes in it. Finally, we note that $I O$ is moderately correlated with the CAUD-based variables. Thus, it too represents a noisy proxy for institutional trading.  

Armed with four workable proxies, we now estimate model (2) augmented by an institutional trading proxy using the quarterly sample. Based on the results in Panel B, we alternatively use volume, the sum of absolute holdings changes, or the corresponding variables scaled by shares outstanding as trading proxies. We report the coefficients for $I O$ and institutional trading in Panel C of Table 6 (the other coefficients in model (2) are estimated but not reported). Similar to the daily results, we find that more institutional trading significantly enhances efficiency. Again, $I O$ retains its effect on efficiency, though its coefficient declines modestly from the levels reported in Table 3. These results are consistent across the four trading measures and across the four measures of efficiency.  

### IV.2 What type of institutional trading affects efficiency?  

The evidence in the prior section reveals that institutional trading is positively related to efficiency. This is a strong result, because our institutional trading measures aggregate the activities of a large number of institutions with heterogeneous trading motives and trading strategies. In this section, we attempt to exploit this heterogeneity to better understand the economic mechanism by which institutions affect efficiency. We begin by differentiating between active and passive trading. Then, we explore the consequences of positive-feedback trading. Finally, we test whether the trading of institutions with strong past performance has a different effect on efficiency than the trading of institutions with weak past performance.  

Institutional order flow can affect efficiency in at least two ways. First, institutions could trade actively on private information. This involves identifying mispriced stocks and then submitting orders in the appropriate direction. Because institutions need to trade before their private information becomes impounded into prices by competing traders, they must use marketable orders that demand liquidity and execute quickly. In this case, information-based theories of market microstructure predict that prices change in response to the private information revealed by the institutions order flow (Glosten and Milgrom 1985, Kyle 1985).  

Second, institutions may not have access to private information about fundamentals but instead be smart traders who can differentiate temporary (uninformed) from permanent (informed) price changes. This would enable these institutions to profit from trading passively. For example, if several large, uninformed buy orders arrive contemporaneously, prices will increase temporarily to induce more sellers to participate in the market (see Chan and Lakonishok, 1993). If institutions are better able than other traders to recognize these buyers as uninformed, they can gain by providing liquidity (trading passively) and closing their position once the buying pressure subsides. To implement this strategy, institutions would place limit orders around the current price when they perceive price movements as uninformed.  

These limit orders would supply liquidity to the uninformed traders and thereby reduce temporary deviations from fundamental value. As a result, this strategy enhances efficiency. Of course, institutions that have private information can use this passive strategy as well (see Bloomfield, O'Hara, and Saar 2005).20  

These arguments suggest that both active and passive trading strategies can have an effect on price efficiency. We use two different approaches to distinguish empirically between active and passive trading. Using the daily sample, we separately observe institutional buying and selling. Because negative return days arise due to overall selling pressure, institutional buying on those days is likely to provide liquidity (implying a passive trading strategy). Similarly, institutional selling provides liquidity on positive return days. In contrast, if institutions trade in the same direction as the return, their trading can be interpreted as liquidity demanding (implying an aggressive trading strategy). A second way of classifying trades relies on a stock's order imbalance. We estimate daily imbalances from TAQ as the number of shares bought net of shares sold, where trade direction is determined using Lee and Ready's (1991) algorithm. Institutions trade “"with" the market if they buy on days with positive trade imbalance or sell on days with negative imbalance. These trades are likely to be aggressive and demand liquidity. In contrast, trades “against’ the market are likely to provide liquidity. In both approaches, we use separate variables for buys and sells because prior work shows that buys tend to be more informative than sells.21  

The first model in Panel A of Table 7 presents the return-based analysis. Both aggressive and passive trading significantly improves efficiency. There is little difference between the effect of buys and sells, but the effect of passive trading is between two and three times as large as the effect of aggressive trading. The second model (based on order imbalances) also shows that both types of trading improve efficiency. But again, passive trades improve efficiency more than aggressive trades, although this difference is twice as large for sells. The key result is that institutional trading improves efficiency  

regardless of the (inferred) trading strategy. Moreover, the daily evidence is consistent with the behavior of informed traders in Bloomfield, O'Hara, and Saar (2005) in that a prominent portion of the effect of trading on efficiency can be attributed to passively trading institutions.  

A sizeable literature presents evidence that institutions are positive-feedback traders in that they purchase securities that have recently performed well and sell securities that have performed poorly.22 Grossman and Stiglitz (1976) and Hellwig (1980) note that such trading practices could be based on rational learning through prices, but others argue that this activity could destabilize prices (Banerjee, 1992; Bikhchandani, Hirshleifer, and Welch, 1992; Welch, 1992). Using a modified version of our quarterly proxies for institutional trading, we can shed some light on this debate. For each stock quarter, we define changes in individual institutional holdings that are in the same direction as returns over the previous quarter as momentum changes, and changes that go the opposite way as contrarian changes. We then sum the absolute value of holdings changes separately for momentum and contrarian changes to obtain proxies for institutional momentum and contrarian trading.  

Panel B of Table 7 presents the relevant coefficients of the quarterly regression. The first model shows that both contrarian and momentum trading significantly improve efficiency. The effect is even slightly more pronounced for momentum than contrarian changes. In the second model, we further split holdings changes by the direction of change and their relationship to past returns to account for a potential buy-sell asymmetry. We find that changes always improve efficiency regardless of their classification, but the effect is stronger and significant only for increases in holdings. Again, momentum changes have a stronger effect on efficiency than do contrarian changes. These results suggest that feedback trading does not reduce the efficiency enhancing effect of institutional trading activity.  

Finally, we construct a test to examine more directly the effect of institution-specific private information on the effect that trading has on efficiency. For the quarterly sample, we can observe the identity of individual institutions and contrast the activities of more informed to less informed institutions.  

To classify institutions as informed or uninformed, we use the characteristic selectivity $(C S)$ measure developed in Daniel et al. (1997). We compute $C S$ based on the approach in Daniel et al. (1997) and Wermers (2004) for each institution-quarter. CS is based on excess returns at the portfolio level as reported in the 13-f data and measures an institution's ability to select stocks that earn excess returns.?? In each quarter, we sort all institutions in the 13-f data on $C S$ averaged over the prior four quarters and classify the top-performing decile as Topl0CS institutions. Then we separately compute our trading proxy, the sum of absolute changes in holdings standardized by shares outstanding, for Top10CS institutions and the rest. If the ability to generate investing alpha is correlated with the ability to take advantage of short-run mispricing, we expect that trading by Topl0CS institutions has a greater effect on efficiency than trading by others. The third model in Panel B lends some support to this hypothesis. While trading by both types of institutions improves efficiency, the effect is $60\%$ stronger for trading by Top10CS institutions.  

Our decompositions of institutional trading activity allow several observations about the effect of institutional trading on price efficiency. First, institutional trading improves efficiency regardless of whether trading strategies are active, passive, momentum, or contrarian. Second, passive trading that provides liquidity and thereby alleviates the effects of temporary buying or selling pressure improves efficiency more than aggressive trading. Third, stock-picking ability appears to facilitate informed shortterm trading, because trading by the best stock pickers has a stronger effect on efficiency than trading by other institutions. Fourth, our evidence mitigates concerns that positive-feedback trading destabilizes prices, because we find that quarterly momentum trading improves efficiency. Taken together, these results suggest that institutional trading is an important mechanism that links institutions and the relative efficiency of prices. The efficiency-enhancing effect of trading does not appear to be limited to a narrow set of trading strategies or specific types of private information. Finally, we note that none of the tradingrelated variables in Table 7 drives out the effect of institutional holdings on efficiency.  

### IV.3  Does variation in liquidity explain the trading effect?  

We argue that institutional trading drives efficiency improvements, but it is possible that this relation arises because of a liquidity effect. As we show in Table 2 and 3, liquidity is positively related to both institutional holdings and efficiency. It is conceivable that institutions concentrate their trading in stocks they expect to be liquid in the future to reduce their expected trading costs. Similar to the discussion in Section IH1.3.1, this implies that the positive relationship between institutional trading and efficiency could be driven by persistence in liquidity.  

To address this concern, we employ a two-stage procedure. First, we decompose cross-sectional variation in institutional trading into liquidity-related and liquidity-unrelated portions by regressing trading on one of five different liquidity proxies. Second, we repeat the regressions in Panels A and C of Table 6, except that we split the trading variable into the predicted (suffix $P$ ) and residual (suffix $R$ components from the first step. In these models, the coefficient on the predicted component measures how efficiency depends on liquidity-related variation in institutional trading, while the coefficient on the residual component reflects how it depends on liquidity-unrelated variation in trading. If institutional trading is only related to efficiency because of its relation to liquidity, we expect significantly negative coefficients on the predicted component and no explanatory power for the residual component. In contrast, if trading has an effect on efficiency beyond what is attributable to variation in liquidity, we expect a significantly negative coefficient on the residual component of institutional trading.  

In Table 8 we present the coefficients of interest for each of the five liquidity proxies. The results for the daily (Panel A) and quarterly (Panel B) samples are inconsistent with the argument that liquidity is responsible for the effect trading has on efficiency. Specifically, regardless of the sample and liquidity measure, we find that only the residual (liquidity-unrelated) component of institutional trading improves efficiency significantly. The liquidity-related component is insignificant except when liquidity is measured as the ratio of quoted spreads and depth. This result is robust across alternative specifications of the first-stage regression. For example, including multiple dimensions of liquidity (effective spread, quoted spread, depth, and price) in the first stage leaves our inferences unchanged for both samples.  

Inferences from Panel B remain also unchanged for the other trading proxies and efficiency variables. In sum, institutional trading has effects on efficiency beyond those atributable to variation in liquidity.24  

### IV.4 Other mechanisms  

A striking feature of our analysis is the consistency with which institutional holdings have a significant incremental effect on efficiency even after controlling for institutional trading. Thus, there appears to be some mechanism beyond trading by which institutional investors affect the efficiency of prices. In this section, we explore when trading can play this role and when it cannot, and then explore potential reasons for the incremental effect of institutional holdings.  

#### IV.4.1  Trading vs. holding  

Bloomfield, O'Hara, and Saar (2005) provide experimental evidence that informed traders exploit and eliminate mispricing more aggressively when their private information is more valuable. All else equal, these traders′ profit opportunities will be more rewarding when prices deviate the most from fundamental values. This suggests that trading in a way that makes prices more efficient is more profitable the greater the degree of mispricing.  

To provide evidence related to this issue, we form quintiles based on previous-quarter efficiency, measured as $V(s)/V(p)$ , which serves as a proxy for the degree of mispricing. We then estimate model (2) separately within each quintile. Panel A in Table 9 reports coefficients on $I O$ and institutional trading for the daily sample, and Panel B reports coefficients on $I O$ and a trading proxy for the quarterly sample. We only report results for institutional trading standardized by shares outstanding, but using the other trading measures does not alter the conclusions. Again, the controls in (2) are included but not reported in the table.  

Within each efficiency quintile, both holdings and trading are positively related to efficiency and their coefficients are significant. The effect of trading becomes stronger, and the effect of holdings  

becomes weaker, as lagged efficiency deteriorates. While this relationship is not strictly monotonic, the effect of trading tends to be more than twice as large in the least efficient stocks than in the most efficient ones. This difference is statistically significant at the $5\%$ level or better in both samples. The difference in IO coefficients between the least and the most efficient quintile is only significant for the daily sample. Taken together, these results suggest that institutions improve the efficiency of prices, but the mechanism that impounds their knowledge into prices differs across stocks. For less efficiently priced stocks, institutional trading is most important because the rewards to eliminating mispricing are presumably the largest. In contrast, the effect of holdings on efficiency is stronger for stocks whose prices are already close to a random walk.  

#### IV.4.2 Explaining the effect of institutional holdings on efficiency  

A surprising finding that we have not yet explored further is that institutional holdings per se are associated with greater efficiency. A possible reason is that the magnitude of holdings is linked to information production. We empirically examine two specific explanations for this link, competition among informed traders and variation in analyst coverage. On one hand, institutions may step up research efforts regarding a particular stock as their holdings increase because they stand to gain more from the acquisition of new information. This suggests that large ownership stakes by individual institutions drive the relation between holdings and efficiency. On the other hand, Holden and Subrahmanyam (1992) show that as the number of informed parties increases, greater competition between them leads to faster price adjustment towards full information values. Thus, to the extent that institutions are informed traders, we expect widely dispersed institutional ownership to be most beneficial to efficiency. To test these alternatives, we use the holdings of individual institutions to construct a Herfindahl index (Herf) for institutional ownership and then add this variable to our cross-sectional regressions. The size-based argument suggests greater efficiency when the concentration of ownership is high, and the competition argument predicts the opposite.  

We report estimates from daily regressions using two different measures of institutional trading in Panel A of Table 10 and estimates from quarterly regressions in Panel B. For both models, the coefficient on Herf is significantly positive, indicating that greater concentration of institutional holdings is related to less efficient prices. As a second test, we split quarterly $I O$ into the largest five holdings and holdings by all other institutions (third and fourth model in Panel A, second model in Panel B). We find that the relation between holdings and efficiency is driven by the holdings of institutions outside of the Top 5 - indeed, holdings by the Top 5 have no effect on efficiency. Finally, we note that the models in Panel A control for institutional trading, so these results imply that lower concentration accelerates information revelation beyond what traders can infer from order flow. These results are consistent with Holden and Subrahmanyam’s (1992) prediction that greater competition among informed traders results in faster incorporation of private information.  

Institutional holdings could also be related to information production via the role of analysts. Brennan and Subrahmanyam (1995) show that the number of sell-side analysts following a stock is positively related to the number of institutions owning shares. They further show that the number of analysts is inversely related to the price impact of trades, a proxy for the information content of order flow. This suggests that analysts affect the intra-day information environment of a firm. To address their potential effect on efficiency, we add the log of the number of analysts covering a stock (from IBES) to our quarterly regression model. The third model in Panel B shows that controlling for analyst coverage has little effect on the relationship between informational efficiency and institutional holdings. Moreover, analyst coverage itself does not impact efficiency. Additionally controlling for institutional trading, even separately for that by the most successful institutions (Topl0CS) as in the fourth model in Panel B, does not alter this result. Therefore, we cannot attribute the holdings effect to increased analyst coverage.  

Finally, a further channel through which institutional holdings could influence efficiency is short selling. Institutionally owned shares are often available for borrowing by short sellers (see Nagel 2005). Because short sellers are highly informed traders (Boehmer, Jones, and Zhang 2007), their trades can make prices more efficient $(\mathrm{Wu}2007\$ . We obtain the actual aggregate amount of short selling for each stock-day in our daily sample. The shorting data are based on proprietary NYSE audit-trail data and are discussed in detail in Boehmer, Jones, and Zhang (2007).  

The last two models in Panel A show daily regressions as in Table 6, but with an additional variable representing total shorting flow in each stock. One of the models standardizes shorting and institutional trading by total volume, the other one by shares outstanding. Short selling significantly increases efficiency, consistent with Wu (2007). But shorting does not drive out institutional holdings or trading, which remain significant in both models. In fact, institutional trading has about the same effect on efficiency as shorting does: a one-standard deviation increase in IVol/Totvol or Ivol/Shrout decreases the pricing error by about the same magnitude as a one-standard deviation increase in shorting.  

Taken together, two of the three mechanisms that we expect to be related to the effect that institutional holdings have on efficiency are relevant. A larger number of institutions in a stock promotes competition and thereby appears to improve efficiency. More short selling also makes prices more efficient, and institutional holdings increase the number of lendable shares. But neither of these explanations drives out institutional holdings - stocks with larger holdings are priced more efficiently, even controlling for competition among informed traders and the amount of short selling.  

# Conclusions  

Institutional shareholdings and trading volume have increased substantially in the past two decades. Yet, we have little evidence on how institutional presence affects the informational efficiency of prices, one important dimension of market quality. Our examination of this issue uses a broad sample of NYSE stocks between 1983 and 2004. We compute different measures of the relative informational efficiency of transaction prices from intra-day transactions during this period and relate these measures to institutional holdings and trading in the cross-section of stocks.  

We find that greater institutional holdings are associated with improved informational efficiency of prices, and this result is robust across different measures of efficiency, different econometric specifications, and a variety of controls. We provide evidence that this result cannot be attributed to reverse causality or to the interaction that market liquidity has with both holdings and efficiency.  

Moreover, our tests suggest a causal link between institutions and efficiency. Overall, this implies that the presence of institutional investors improves the information environment of a firm.  

We examine several economic mechanisms that could explain this result. First, using proprietary audit trail data, we find that institutional trading activity makes prices more efficient. We also use these proprietary data to create quarterly proxies for institutional trading from public 13-f data, and employ these proxies to corroborate our result in a longer panel. Moreover, we show that the underlying trading strategy has little effect on the efficiency-enhancing effect of institutional trading. We obtain three interesting results in this context: (1) trading by institutions that are successful stock pickers improves efficiency more than trading by other institutions, indicating that their trading reveals private information; (2) institutional trading improves efficiency even when it is based on positive-feedback strategies, inconsistent with the view that positive-feedback trading makes prices noisier; and (3) even passive trading that is not necesarily based on private information about fundamentals can improve efficiency.  

In addition to institutional trading, the level of institutional holdings has a strong effect on efficiency, even when controlling for institutional trading, liquidity, and firm characteristics. This is a somewhat puzzling result and we provide an exploratory analysis of its causes. First, we show that more institutional holdings improve efficiency more when holdings are more dispersed. This is consistent with arguments that atribute faster price adjustment to fundamental values to greater competition among informed traders. Second, it is well known that greater institutional holdings increase the activities of two types of market participants who are presumed to be more informed than others: analysts and short sellers. We find no evidence that analysts have an effect on efficiency but document that short selling makes prices more efficient. But neither analyst coverage nor short selling drives out the explanatory power of institutional holdings (or that of institutional trading). Thus, further research is necessary to explain why institutional holdings per se affect efficiency. Perhaps this relationship arises because other market participants focus more on stocks with greater institutional holdings. For example, conversations with NYSE members indicate that specialists often pay additional attention to stocks with high institutional ownership. During our sample period, each NYSE specialist makes a market in about twelve different securities, but their trading screens cannot present equal detail on each of those stocks. Therefore, they must focus their attention on a smaller subset, for which they might follow trading activity more closely (irrespective of who is trading). Such activity serves as another viable channel through which stocks with high institutional ownership become more efficiently priced.  

While our measures of the relative efficiency of prices concentrate on the short run, we believe that the effects we document are distinct from the dimensions of market quality typically assessed in studies of market microstructure. In particular, we use a range of liquidity measures to control for execution costs throughout the analysis, so the effect we ascribe to institutional investors goes beyond simple reductions in trading costs. Moreover, we show that longer-term measures based on variance ratios up to a one-month horizon yield very similar conclusions.  

In a broader sense, the informational efficiency of prices is a valuable public good—all market participants benefit from more efficient prices. Our finding that institutions improve efficiency contributes to the debate on how their increasing presence in securities markets affects market quality. We document that one channel through which institutions influence efficiency is through their trading, but our results also indicate that other channels exist that link institutions’ activities to security prices. It seems important for future research efforts to identify these additional channels through which these efficiency improvements materialize, because the precise nature and the scope of the process is likely to have important implications for the optimal design of markets, trading protocols, and regulatory policy.

# The Effects of Institutional Investor Objectives on Firm Valuation and Governance \*  

Paul Borochin School of Business University of Connecticut  

Jie Yang Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Systemt  

This version: November, 2016  

## Abstract  

We find that ownership by different types of institutional investor has different implications for future firm misvaluation and governance characteristics. Dedicated institutional investors decrease future firm misvaluation relative to fundamentals. as well as the magnitude of this misvaluation. In contrast, transient institutional investors have the opposite effect. Using SEC Regulation FD as an exogenous shock to information dissemination, we find evidence consistent with dedicated institutions having an information advantage. The valuation effects are primarily driven by institutional portfolio concentration while the governance effects are driven by portfolio turnover. These results imply a more nuanced relationship between institutional ownership and firm value and corporate governance.  

Keywords: Institutional investors, investor type, dedicated, transient, misvaluation, corporate governance, blockholding, portfolio turnover, information dissemination, SEC Regulation FD

# The Effects of Institutional Investor Objectives on Firm Valuation and Governance  

This version: November, 2016  

## Abstract  

We find that ownership by different types of institutional investor has different implications for future firm misvaluation and governance characteristics. Dedicated institutional investors decrease future firm misvaluation relative to fundamentals. as well as the magnitude of this misvaluation. In contrast, transient institutional investors have the opposite effect. Using SEC Regulation FD as an exogenous shock to information dissemination, we find evidence consistent with dedicated institutions having an information advantage. The valuation effects are primarily driven by institutional portfolio concentration while the governance effects are driven by portfolio turnover. These results imply a more nuanced relationship between institutional ownership and firm value and corporate governance.  

Keywords: Institutional investors, investor type, dedicated, transient, misvaluation, corporate governance, blockholding, portfolio turnover, information dissemination, SEC Regulation FD  

JEL classification: G30, G32, G14, G38 "Institutional investors are not all the same. They come in many different forms and with many different characteristics."  

- Commissioner Luis Aguilar, SEC, April 2013  

## 1 Introduction  

Institutional equity ownership has risen dramatically in the last 30 years, inviting a more thorough investigation into its effects on firm valuation and operations. In the 1980s, institutional investors held approximately 20%-30% of the average frm (with individual investors making up the rest). By the 2010s, over 65% of the average frm is owned by institutional investors.1 This increase in institutional holdings coincides with the growing sophistication of markets and growing importance of corporate governance. Indeed, much of the literature focuses on the informed "smart money” of the institutional investor in contrast to the less sophisticated individual “retail" investor. Barber and Odean (2008) confirm that, unlike institutions, individual investors are net buyers of attention-grabbing stocks due to limited search resources. This ability of institutional investors to gather information and impose market discipline on management should translate into improvements in market efficiency and asset valuation. For example, Sias and Starks (1997) find that institutional trading increases the speed of adjustment of information into prices and Nagel (2005) finds that short sale constraints bind for stocks with low institutional ownership, resulting in underperformance.  

Yet, as suggested in a speech by Commissioner Luis Aguilar of the SEC,2 not all institutional owners are alike nor do they have similar effects on firms. While many characteristics differentiate institutional investors from one another, portfolio turnover and holdings concentration are the most fundamental. For example, Bushee (1998, 2001) finds that short-term, low concentration ("transient") investors lead to myopic investment decision-making by managers and over-weighting of near-term expected earnings to the detriment of long-term earnings. As such, myopic investment behavior leads to myopic corporate decision-making, potentially destroying long-run value for the frm. In addition, Yan and Zhang (2009) show that the pricing impact of large institutional investors is largely driven by short-term investors reacting and trading on new information. These findings suggest that, subsets of institutional investors with different holdings horizons and portfolio concentrations may have differential impact on corporate decisions and firm valuation.  

In this paper, we study the impact of different institutional investor types on the valuation, corporate governance, and future performance of firms. Specifically, we focus on two fundamental investor characteristics, portfolio turnover and holdings concentration. We begin by using the Bushee (1998, 2001) classification of institutions into “transient” and “dedicated" investor types. Institutional investors are “transient” if they take small positions in the frms they hold and have high portfolio turnover. Due to a short investment horizon and lack of focus on particular frms, these investors are likely to be myopic traders looking for short-term gains. On the other hand, "dedicated" investors take highly concentrated positions in the firms they hold and have low portfolio turnover. Both of these portfolio characteristics suggest dedicated investors are more likely to invest for the long run, gathering costly firm-specific information and trading on growth potential of a firm. Bushee (1998) finds evidence consistent with this interpretation as firms with predominantly dedicated (transient) institutional owners invest more (less) in R&D. Figure 1 shows that transient institutional investors comprise an increasingly large portion of the total institutional investor pool over time, making an investigation into the effects of different institutional investor types particularly relevant.  

We find that frms with higher percentages of transient (dedicated) institutional investors experience more (less) subsequent overvaluation and misvaluation. Specifically, using the RhodesKropf, Robinson, and Viswanathan (2005) book-to-market decomposition, frms with more transient (dedicated) institutional investors experience more (less) positive firm-specific deviation from fundamental values in the following quarter, consistent with overvaluation. They also experience more (less) of an absolute deviation from fundamental value in the next quarter, consistent with misvaluation. Furthermore, firms that experience an increase in their percentage of transient (dedicated) institutional investors experience more (less) overvaluation and misvaluation in the next quarter.  These effects persist after controlling for common firm characteristics that may impact firm valuation and after considering alternative explanations such as perceived growth opportunities. In the appendix, we obtain similar results using alternative definitions of overvaluation and misvaluation based on the Hirshleifer and Jiang (2010) undervalued minus  

overvalued factor.3  

We posit that the differential impact of transient versus dedicated institutional investors on subsequent firm overvaluation and misvaluation is driven by differences in information gathering. To examine the information channel, we explore the relationship between institutional investor types and firm valuation around the enactment of SEC Regulation FD. Regulation FD, enacted in 20o0 by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, mandates that when an issuer discloses material non-public information to specific outsiders (e.g., analysts or institutional investors), this disclosure must be made public, thereby eliminating the informational advantage previously enjoyed by blockholders (Francis, Nanda, and Wang, 2006; Anderson, Reeb, Zhang, and Zhao, 2013). As such, this regulation addresses the problem of selective disclosure of material information and provides a natural experiment in which to test the information channel.  

Using a difference-in-difference framework we find that, as expected, Regulation FD has no significant impact on the relationship between dedicated investor ownership and subsequent overvaluation and misvaluation.  That is, dedicated institutional investor ownership reduces overvaluation and misvaluation to a similar degree before and after the regulation, consistent with their having access to information both prior to and after Regulation FD. On the other hand, the regulation significantly reduced the subsequent overvaluation and misvaluation for firms with above-median levels of transient investors relative to the preceding time period, consistent with transient investors having lower barriers to access of information previously only enjoyed by dedicated investors. These results do not exist using a placebo event year of 1995.  

Although we use a model with lagged changes in institutional ownership type on overvaluation and misvaluation, the observed results may be due to self-selection by investors into certain types of firms rather than a causal effect of ownership type on firm valuation. We create samples matched exante on misvaluation in a difference-in-difference-in-difference framework to control for self-selection issues in the appendix. We obtain similar results.  

Having established that transient and dedicated institutional investors have differential impact on subsequent firm overvaluation and misvaluation, we next explore which of the associated portfolio characteristics - portfolio turnover or holdings concentration - is responsible for these findings to shed further light on the causes of differences between the two previously defined institutional types. We find that ownership by institutions in the lowest portfolio turnover tercile (i.e., long horizon investors) results in less firm-specific overvaluation as well as lower misvaluation relative to fundamentals in the subsequent quarter. Institutional ownership by investors in the highest portfolio turnover tercile also results in less overvaluation, but statistically insignificant misvaluation. Importantly, frms held by institutions that have diversified portfolios and either high or low portfolio turnover experience more future overvaluation.  

Finally, we explore whether institutional ownership types also have differential effects on measures of risk, corporate governance, and future frm performance. We document that firms held by transient institutional investors have more expected tail risk, higher realized returns volatility, higher average and median executive compensation, worse accruals quality, lower payout ratios, and lower leverage increases relative to those held by dedicated institutional investors. Firms held by transient investors experience positive abnormal returns relative to the 5-factor model in the subsequent quarter, whereas those held by dedicated investors experience positive abnormal performance later in the year consistent with longer investment horizons. Firms held by dedicated investors experience positive raw returns over the subsequent four quarters, whereas those held by transient investors experience negative or insignificant raw returns over the same period.  

These findings enable us to contribute to the ongoing debate within extant literature over whether institutional investors benefit the markets, either through improvements in market efficiency or by providing corporate governance, or whether they harm them through opportunism and pressure exerted on managers to achieve short-term results at the expense of long-term performance. While the literature generally accepts that institutional investors are more informed and allow markets to be more effcient (Sias and Starks, 1997; Nagel, 2005; Barber and Odean, 2008), there are contradicting results and arguments among both academics and practitioners over the institutional benefits to governance and costs of induced myopia. For example, Gillian (1995), Karpoff, Malatesta, and Walkling (1996), Smith (1996), and Wahal (1996) find no long-term effects from shareholder activism while Nesbitt (1994) finds that firms targeted by CalPERS outperform in subsequent years. More recently, Brav, Jiang, Partnoy, and Thomas (2008) find a positive abnormal return for firms targeted by hedge fund activism and Boone and White (2015) find that higher institutional ownership is associated with greater management disclosure and lower information asymmetry. Conversely, a survey of over 1,0oo board members and executives around the world conducted by the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and McKinsey and Company (Barton and Wiseman, 2014) draws attention to the effects of short-term investor pressure on corporate decision-making and its negative effects on value maximization. In this report, 79% of respondents felt pressured to demonstrate performance over a horizon of two years or less, and 44% used a horizon of three or less years to set corporate strategy while 86% stated that a longer horizon would have improved financial performance.  

These seemingly dissonant effects of institutional ownership on firm performance can be explained by the diferential effects we find for institutional ownership types. The conficting findings in the growing literature above suggest that combining all institutions into one category yields different, and likely mistaken, results than those that would be obtained by more refined categorizations. Indeed, among the papers that find benefits to corporate governance, most focus on a specific type of institutional investor (e.g., CalPERS or hedge funds) rather than institutional investors as a single group.  

The main contribution of our paper lies in identifying the distinct effects of institutional investor types and investment styles on subsequent firm overvaluation, misvaluation, governance measures, and realized future performance. Bushee (1998, 2001) groups institutional investors based on their portfolio turnover and holdings concentration and finds that “transient" institutional investors are related to myopic corporate decision-making while “dedicated" institutional investors are not. Gompers and Metrick (2001) find that large institutional investors invest in large companies, thereby increasing the prices of large stocks. Yan and Zhang (2009) show that these trends in large institutional investors is largely driven by short-term investors reacting and trading on new information. On the other hand, Gasper, Massa, and Matos (2005) show that acquisition targets held by short-term investors experience a lower premium and Chen, Harford, and Li (2007) find that only long-term investors are related to positive post-merger performance rather than focusing on short-term gains.  

We add to this growing literature by identifying how institutional investor types and their underlying portfolio turnover and holdings concentration affect the valuation, governance characteristics, and future performance of firms in which these institutions invest.  We find that dedicated institutional investor ownership results in more accurate future firm valuation, superior characteristics related to corporate governance, and superior long-term performance of the frm. The valuation effects are primarily improved by institutional investors with higher portfolio concentration and the governance and long-term performance effects by institutions with lower portfolio turnover. Specifically, we find that long-term institutions are able to achieve long-term performance: firms with more long-term institutional investors outperform firms with fewer of them by 2.8% on a risk-adjusted basis over the subsequent year.  

## 2 Data  

### 2.1 Institutional Ownership and Investor Types  

We start with data on institutional investor ownership obtained from the Thomson Reuters Institutional Holdings database.  The Thomson Reuters holdings database covers investment companies and their security holdings as reported on their 13F forms filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) every quarter.4  

We first classify institutional investor types based on the combination of portfolio turnover and holdings concentration from Bushee (1998, 2001) and Bushee and Noe (2000). Bushee (1998, 2001) categorizes institutional investors as “transient", “"quasi-indexer", or “dedicated" based on their investment horizons and portfolio concentration.5 Investors are classified as “transient” if they have short investment horizons refected by high portfolio turnover and highly diversified portfolio holdings.6 Analogously, “dedicated" investors have long investment horizons refected by low portfolio turnover and focused portfolio holdings. The third class of investors, “quasiindexers", are long-horizon, low turnover investors that are highly diversified. We focus our analysis on dedicated (DED) and transient (TRA) institutional investors as they both have an active choice in their investment strategy: dedicated investors do not trade frequently, but hold specifically selected frms (and are therefore different from the passive indexers), while transient investors trade frequently. We exclude the quasi-indexer institutional ownership type as the passive ownership strategy does not imply any asset selection in either the time horizon or portfolio choice dimensions.  

Table I presents the top ten dedicated and transient institutional investors in our sample in decreasing order based on average portfolio size. As expected, the dedicated list of investors is comprised of investment management and insurance companies, which may be expected to hold stocks for long periods of time and some of which, like Berkshire Hathaway, are famous for it. On the other hand, many of the investment management frms on the transient list of investors are affliated with investment banks such as UBS, Morgan Stanley, and Oppenheimer.  

To further motivate the distinctions between the two types of institutional investors, we consider empirical differences in their portfolio characteristics. Table II demonstrates that dedicated and transient institutions have different investment styles, as reflected in their significantly different portfolio characteristics. Dedicated institutional investors have average portfolio sizes almost four times larger than transient investors, though they hold fewer stocks on average. Additionally, dedicated investors hold a larger percentage of each firm on average, and at the median, than transients do. They also have a significantly higher variation in these holdings, consistent with the large positions of dedicated blockholders.7 Notably, dedicated investors hold firms with smaller average and median market capitalizations that are almost half the size of those held by transients, with a correspondingly lower variability in owned-firm capitalizations. This is consistent with dedicated investors possessing an information advantage, as smaller and younger frms are more opaque and difficult to analyze (Hadlock and Pierce, 2010; Karpoff, Lee, Masulis, 2013). As expected, dedicated investors are also more focused, holding frms from fewer unique SIC3 industries and have a much higher Hirshleifer-Herfindahl concentration in portfolio weights than do transient investors. Reassuringly, consistent with the Bushee (1998, 2001) definition, dedicated investors do indeed have more concentrated positions in firms relative to total shares outstanding and have lower portfolio turnover than transients. All institutional investor characteristics between dedicated and transient institutional investors are significantly different at the 1% level.  

### 2.2 Misvaluation  

Our main measure of misvaluation is the Rhodes-Kropf, Robinson, and Viswanathan (2005), hereafter RKRV, decomposition which splits the logarithm of the market-to-book ratio into three components: firm-specific error, time-series sector error, and long-run market value to book value. The RKRV decomposition is provided in equation (3) of their paper and reproduced below:  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{m_{i,t}-b_{i,t}=\underbrace{m_{i,t}-v(\theta_{i,t};a_{j,t})}_{f i r m}+\underbrace{v(\theta_{i,t};a_{j,t})-v(\theta_{i,t};a_{j})}_{s e c t o r}+\underbrace{v(\theta_{i,t};a_{j})-b_{i,t}}_{l o n g-r u n}.}\end{array}
$$  

This decomposition relies on a firm having a long-run, target, market-to-book ratio that equals that of its industry. This ratio is determined by a parsimonious set of valuation multiples: book value, leverage, and net income.8 The firm's market-to-book ratio is comprised of a long-run market-to-book value determined from long-run multiples of the three variables used, with a time-varying sector-wide multiple representing sector-wide deviations and a frm-specific multiple accounting for any additional firm-specific deviations. Following Rhodes-Kropf, Robinson, and Viswanathan (2005), these firm-specific deviations capture the degree of overvaluation and misvaluation. We explore the impact of the different types of institutional investor on the firmspecific error component. Positive firm-specific error is our proxy for overvaluation, and the absolute value of the firm-specific error proxies for misvaluation.9  

### 2.3Financial Statement Data

Such firms have either unreliable Compustat data or are likely to be distressed or severely unprofitable. In addition, we delete observations in which book assets or sales growth over the quarter is greater than 1 or less than -1 and remove firms worth less than \$5 million in 2000 dollars in book value or market value to remove observations that have abnormally large changes due to acquisitions or small asset bases. Next, we remove outliers defined as firm-quarter observations that are in the first and 99th percentile tails for all relevant variables used in our analysis. Following standard practice in the literature, we remove all firms in the financial and insurance, utilities, and public administration industries as they tend to be heavily regulated.  

Merging institutional investor data to corporate financial data based on a frm's CUSIP and year-quarter gives us a sample of 236,025 firm-quarter observations spanning 11,116 frms. Appendix A details the construction of all variables. Table II provides the summary statistics for our main sample and Table IV presents the correlation matrix. The average (median) frm in our sample has 41.5% (38.4%) institutional ownership, with 4.6% (2.9%) of the frm owned by dedicated institutional investors and $27.3\%$ (27.3%) owned by transient institutional investors. The correlation between dedicated and institutional ownership is -0.23.10 While there is a wide range of frm overvaluation, the average and median frm in our sample is overvalued (i.e., has positive firm-specific error) according to the RKRV measure.  

In Table V, we compare key characteristics of frms held by the two types of active institutional investors. We subset the data on the highest half of ownership by each investor type and find that the two active types hold firms with significantly different characteristics. This is consistent with the different investment styles and objectives evident in their different approaches to holding period and concentration. Notable differences in the firms each type chooses to hold signal potential notably different effects on firm valuation, operations, and performance. Specifically, we find that dedicated institutional investors hold larger firms than transient investors do, with average total asset values of \$1,763.4 and \$1,434.2 million respectively. Despite this, dedicated investors hold firms with lower market values than those held by transient investors, with average market values of \$1,632.5 and \$1,741.9 million respectively. These two observations taken together imply a value preference by dedicated investors relative to transient ones; indeed the log of long-run market-tobook ratio under the RKRV decomposition is significantly lower for firms held by dedicated (0.479) relative to transient institutional investors (0.578). Dedicated investors also hold firms with lower analyst following, 3.3 to 4.9 respectively, as well as a higher principal component of several opacity measures,ll consistent with an informational advantage in selecting less-followed and more opaque firms. Firms held by dedicated investors are also less likely to have a credit rating, further consistent with a preference of dedicated investors in holding firms with less publicly available information.  

Dedicated investors also hold firms with significantly different operating characteristics than those held by transient investors: they have higher Z-scores, higher leverage, lower cash fow dispersion, lower realized volatility, lower tai or crash risk for firm cash flowsl risk, $_{12}$ lower average, maximum, and median executive pay, higher quality accruals, higher payout ratios, and higher net leverage changes.  

Overall, these results are strongly indicative of differing investment preferences by the two institutional investor types, motivating our study of the effects of intuitional ownership type on future firm value. The overlap between firms owned by dedicated, transient, long/short horizon, and focused/diversified institutional investors is imperfect but consistent with expectations. Firms owned by an above-median number of dedicated investors also have more long-horizon institutional investors. The differences observed in Table V also hold when we subsample frms based on the dollar amount held by each institutional ownership type (i.e., value-weighted), rather than by the number of each institutional investor type (i.e., equal-weighted).  

## 3  Institutional Investor Type and Firm Value  

In this section, we examine the impact of different institutional investors types on overvaluation and misvaluation. We begin with classifying institutional investors as dedicated or transient, following Bushee (1998, 2001). Transient investors are more likely to enter and exit their positions quickly and aggressively, relying on publicly available information and strategies such as technical analysis to choose their investments (Bushee, 2001). In contrast, dedicated investors have more incentive to gather information and build relationships with their investments. Due to the information advantage that dedicated investors have relative to transient investors, we hypothesize that firms with more transient institutional investors will have more future overvaluation and misvaluation while firms with more dedicated institutional investors will have less. Furthermore, if dedicated investors possess an informational advantage an increase in dedicated institutional investors should lead to a decrease in overvaluation and misvaluation, with the opposite effect occurring for increases in transient institutional ownership.  

Hypothesis 1. Firms with a higher percentage of dedicated (transient) institutional investors ecperience less (more) overvaluation and misvaluation.  

Hypothesis 2. Firms that experience an increase in dedicated (transient) institutional investors experience less (more) overvaluation and misvaluation.  

### 3.1 Baseline and Full Models  

Starting with a baseline model, we estimate the effects of lagged levels of institutional ownership by investor type on overvaluation and misvaluation variables of interest, $Y_{i,t}$ , in the subsequent quarter. We consider two measures: 1) the RKRV firm-specific valuation error, which captures the direction of valuation error with positive error indicating overvaluation, and 2) the absolute value of the RKRV firm-specific error which captures the magnitude of misvaluation regardless of direction of deviation from fundamental value.  

$$
Y_{i,t}=\alpha+\beta_{1}p D E D_{i,t-1}+\beta_{2}p T R A_{i,t-1}+f e_{t}+f e_{j}+\varepsilon_{i,t},
$$  

where $p D E D$ is the percentage of dedicated institutional owners relative to the total number of institutional owners, and $p T R A$ is the percentage of transient institutional owners relative to the total number of institutional owners. We control for macroeconomic effects with year fixed effects, for seasonality with quarter fixed effects, and for general changes in value with industry fixed effects. $$

First, it allows us to study the impact of levels as well as changes of ownership type on firm value. Second, it controls for any persistence in institutional ownership through the second lag level, allowing the change in ownership to act as a shock. Third, although imperfect, it serves as a first attempt to address the potential selection bias issue in controlling for the relationship between firm valuation and pre-existing ownership types. We address the potential selection bias more rigorously in Section 4.1 and in the appendix.

### 3.2  Channels for Ownership Effects on Firm Value  

Having observed the differing effects that institutional investor types have on firm-specific overvaluation and misvaluation, we next seek to understand and test several explanations by which these differences may arise.  

#### 3.2.1 Corporate Events  

First, one potential reason for the observed differences is due to the occurrence of corporate events in which one type of institutional investor is involved in some capacity, resulting in both increased ownership by that investor type as well as increased (over) valuation. One such corporate event is merger and acquisition activity in which transient institutions may either engage in event-specific trading strategies or in advisory roles. To examine whether mergers and acquisitions drive the relationship between investor type and misvaluation, we obtain and include mergers and acquisition information from the Thomson Reuters SDC M&A database. We repeat our full model analysis in equation (4) using three alternative subsamples: 1) excluding firms that have participated in M&A (as either the acquirer or target) in the current quarter, 2) excluding frms that have participated in M&A in the quarter before, during, and after the current, and 3) excluding firms that have ever participated in M&A in its entire available history. In all cases, our results are highly similar to the main findings in Table VI, suggesting that investor involvement or infuence in M&A is not the main driver of investor type on misvaluation.  

Another such corporate event is equity offerings. It may be the case that transient investors, many of whom are large investment banks, may act in advisory roles, inflating both the valuation of the firm as well as transient ownership. To consider the effect of equity offerings, we obtain and include seasoned equity offering information from the Thomson Reuters SDC Global Issuances database. Similarly to the treatment of M&A, we consider three alternative subsamples: 1) excluding frms that have issued an equity offering in the current quarter, 2) excluding firms that have issued equity in the quarter before, during, and after the current, and 3) excluding firms that have ever participated in a seasoned equity offering in its entire available history. Again, in all cases, our results are highly similar to the main findings. Altogether, these results suggest that corporate events are not the main driver of the observed effect of institutional ownership type on firm value. These results are suppressed for brevity.  

#### 3.2.2 Momentum  

A second potential explanation for the observed differences between different institutional investor types could be that, given the high portfolio turnover and short investment horizon characteristics of transient investors, these investors may be momentum return chasers. A momentum trend could jointly cause an increase in both current transient ownership and future firm-specific RKRV overvaluation and misvaluation.15  We create a Momentum Returns measure calculated as the cumulative return over the prior 12 to seven months following Novy-Marx (2012) to control for this potential confounding effect.16 Novy-Marx (2012) shows that intermediate-term past returns serve better in predicting future returns than recent past performance. Using intermediate-term past returns has the additional advantage of basing momentum on a period prior to our lagged institutional investor level and change measures.  

Columns (1) and (2) of Table VII include the Momentum Returns variable to control for momentum trends in firm value. The coefficients on both dedicated and transient institutional ownership types, their significances, and the $R^{2}$ 's are highly similar to those observed in our main findings in Table VI. This rules out momentum chasing as the driving explanatory mechanism for the observed overvaluation effect of transient institutional investors. As expected, Momentum Returns, itself, increases firm overvaluation significant at the $1\%$ level as firms experiencing upward momentum in the past intermediate-term will on average continue to exceed their firm-specific fundamental value.  

#### 3.2.3 Firm Opacity  

Third, we examine the possibility that the observed differences between dedicated versus transient investors on overvaluation and misvaluation is due to different investor incentives in gathering information. As such, we would expect any information advantages that dedicated investors use in correcting valuation errors to be stronger for more opaque firms, and transient-induced mispricing to be higher. We measure Firm Opacity as the principal component of known opacity proxies following the approach of Karpoff, Lee, and Masulis (2013) to control for information asymmetry. These opacity proxies include log of firm age, log of firm size, and average bid-ask spread, standard deviation of returns, Amihud ratio, and skewness of the Fama-French 3-factor model residuals over the prior year.17 Since this principal component includes the Amihud ratio and bid-ask spread, this effectively controls for firm liquidity as well.18  

Columns (3) and (4) of Table VII include the Firm Opacity measure as an additional control for availability of information. This appears to strengthen our results from Columns (5) and (6) of Table VI with higher magnitude coefficients on the levels of and changes in dedicated ownership for firm overvaluation and levels of and changes in transient ownership for firm misvaluation and the $R^{2}$ 's are the highest among all specifications we consider. Firm Opacity itself lowers overvaluation and increases misvaluation. This is consistent with information asymmetries playing a role in the effect of institutional investor types on firm valuation, particularly that of dedicated institutional investors with a superior information advantage. We revisit the role of information gathering on the observed results in more detail in Section 4.  

#### 3.2.4  Perceived Growth Opportunities  

Finally, it may also be the case that dedicated and transient institutional investors have distinct perceptions regarding the growth and future value of firms, driving the observed differences in results. Specifically, higher perceived growth opportunities may drive both transient ownership and increased firm overvaluation and misvaluation. To address this concern, we rely on the frm's investment in innovation as a proxy for perceived growth opportunities. We measure R&D Intensity, defined as annual research and development expenses as a ratio to annual sales revenue, to capture the degree to which a firm invests in innovation and growth. A frm with more R&D investment is harder to value correctly given the long-term nature of the investment and is more likely to generate diverging perceptions of growth.19 As such, R&D Intensity proxies for perceived future growth opportunities.  

Columns (5) and (6) of Table VII include R&D Intensity as a control for perceived growth opportunities. The results for the effect of institutional ownership type on frm-specific overvaluation and misvaluation are unchanged - dedicated (transient) institutional investors leads to significantly lower (higher) overvaluation in the next quarter and transient institutional investors lead to significantly higher misvaluation in the next quarter.  

### 3.3  Sector-wide Misvaluation and Long-run Value  

In the previous section, we study the relationship between institutional investor types and frmspecific overvaluation and misvaluation, including using a firm-specific proxy for differences in perceived growth opportunities. To further explore whether frm-specific characteristics such as perceived growth opportunities drive the observed diferences between investor types and firm valuation, we examine the effect of institutional ownership type on sector-wide misvaluation and long-run market-to-book value from the remaining two components of the RKRV decomposition in equation (1). These components eliminate firm-specific cross-sectional differences, including frmspecific perceived growth opportunities, and allows us to examine institutional investor objectives at the sector level as well as in the long-run.  

The RKRV sector overvaluation is defined by Rhodes-Kropf, Robinson, and Viswanathan (2005) as the difference between the log of firm value derived from current sector multiples and the log of firm value derived from long-run sector multiples. The RKRV long-run market-to-book value is the difference between the log of fundamental value derived from long-run multiples and the log of book value. Similar to the frm-specific misvaluation measure, we create a sector-wide misvaluation measure as the absolute value of the sector-wide overvaluation measure.
